## Deuterostome clade
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 48%;">

* **Phylum Echinoderms (Invertebrates)**
* **Phylum Chordata (mostly Vertebrates)**

<br/>

* **Deuterostome = Developmental similarities**
    + radial cleavage of embryo
    + anus forms first (then mouth)

<br/>

* **HOWEVER: other animal phyla share some of these traits**
    + Deuterostomes now defined by DNA

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:180px; LEFT:550px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:250px" SRC="images/brittle.jpg">

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:375px; LEFT:550px; WIDTH:400px; HEIGHT:250px" SRC="images/reptile.jpg">

## Protostome vs Deuterostome
<hr>
**Groups differ in how the digestive system developes**
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:180px; LEFT:25px; WIDTH:600px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/phyla2.jpg">

<div style="float: right; width: 40%;">

* **Two groups differ by embryonic development of the blastopore (the first developmental opening) and the alignment of embryonic cells after fertilization**

<br/>

* **Protostome = Mouth develops first**

<br/>

* <span style="color:blue">**Deuterostome = Mouth develops second**</span>

</div>

## Phylum Echinoderms

* **Thin epidermis covered in hard plates**
    + often with bumps or spines

## Phylum Chordata (mostly vertebrates)
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

* **All chordates share 4 traits**
* **Some only in embryo stages**
1. <span style="color:blue">Notochord</span>
2. <span style="color:blue">Dorsal, hollow nerve cord</span>
3. <span style="color:blue">Pharyngeal slits</span>
4. <span style="color:blue">Muscular, Post-anal tail</span>

<br/>

* **2 invertebrates groups that are more related to vertebrates**
    + Cephlachordata (lancelets)
    + Urochordates (tunicates)

</div>

## <span style="color:blue">Vertebrates</span> are chordates with a backbone
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Possess skeletal and nervous systems**
    + simple to complex backbones
    + lots of unique genes (eg. HOX)

<br/>
<br/>

* **Derived trait = <span style="color:blue">neural crest</span>**
    + special stem cells near neural tube in embryo
    + give rise to many vertebrate traits
    + e.g.. teeth, skull, cartilage, etc

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:275px; LEFT:550px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:250px" SRC="images/brach.jpg">

## History of backbones: ~525 million years old
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Evolved while predators where developing**
    + Cambrian period
    + Ocean origins

<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Vertebrate</span>: series of *bones* that make up the vertebral column**
    + 57,000 species

<br/>

* **Vertebrates with limbs colonized land 365 mya**
1. Amphibians
2. Reptiles (w/ birds)
3. Mammals

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:570px; WIDTH:500px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/verts.jpg">

## Hagfish and Lampreys
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Only members of vertebrates without jaws**
    + <span style="color:blue">sister group of jawless fish</span>

<br/>

* **Have rudimentary backbones**
    + more cartilage than bone

<br/>

* **Hagfish escape by releasing slime**
    + slime threads act as hydrogel and rapidly expand when mixed with water
    + researched to stop bleeding in surgery

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:575px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/hagfish.jpg">

## Sharks and rays
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **<span style="color:blue">'Cartilage fishes'</span>: skeletons mostly cartilage**
    + often with calcium
    + originated 400 mya
    
<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Streamlined body</span> for swift swimming**
    + poor maneuverability
    + stay in near constant motion
    
<br/>

* **Birth via eggs or young develop inside mother**

<br/>

* **Modern species diversity massively reduced**

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:575px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/sharks.jpg">

## Ray-finned and Lobe-finned fishes (lungs on phylogeny)
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

* **Important derived traits for fishes:**
    + <span style="color:blue">operculum</span>:
    + <span style="color:blue">swim bladder</span>:

<br/>

* **Ray-finned: bony rays that support fins**
  + trout, sea horses, eels

<br/>

* **<span style="color:blue">Lobe-finned</span>: rod-shaped bone surrounded by muscle in fins**
  + lungfish, *Coelacanths*, earliest tetrapods

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:500px; WIDTH:550px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/fishes.jpg">

## Evolution had to solve a density problem for bony fishes
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 48%;">

* **A fish has a density of about 1.076**
    + freshwater has a density of 1.0
    + saltwater has a density of 1.026

<br/>

* **Bone is nearly twice as dense as cartilage**

<br/>

* **Swimming is energy expensive**
  + resting on the bottom may not be practical
 
 <br/>
 
* **Evolution of the swim bladder set fish free**

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:170px; LEFT:650px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/swimbladder.png">

## Evolution of <span style="color:blue">Tetrapod group</span>
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 45%;">

* **Lobe fins gradually evolved into limbs**
    + Tetrapods colonized land 365 mya
    + move away from fish-like vertebrates

<br/>
<br/>

* **Tetrapod derived trait = <span style="color:blue">limbs with digits</span>**
    + supports weight
    + digits efficiently support movement

</div>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:170px; LEFT:525px; WIDTH:475px; HEIGHT:475px" SRC="images/tiktak2.jpg">

## Tiktaalik fossil (aka 'Fishapod')
<hr>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:15px; WIDTH:600px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/tiktak3.jpg">

<div style="float: right; width: 43%;">

* **Fossils found in river beds**

<br/>

* **Selection of many terrestrial traits**
    + head separated from body by a neck
    + more vertebrate to allow head to swing
    + bones of pelvis fuse to backbone
    + many species lost gills (became ears)

</div>

## Amphibians (frogs and salamanders)
<hr>
<br/>

<IMG STYLE="position:absolute; TOP:190px; LEFT:75px; WIDTH:350px; HEIGHT:450px" SRC="images/frogs.jpg">

<div style="float: right; width: 55%;">

* **Include salamanders, frogs and caecilians**
    + >6,000 species
    + caecilians lost legs

<br/>

* **Rely on <span style="color:blue">skin for gas exchange</span>**
    + live in moist habitats

<br/>

* **Name means 'dual life'**
    + some have aquatic tadpole larvae
    + more related to metamorphosis
    + gills &rarr; legs, lungs, eardrums

</div>

## Mammals
<hr>
<br/>

<div style="float: left; width: 50%;">

* **Large adaptive radiation post dinosaurs**
    + predators, herbivores, flying, aquatic
    + *Monotremes* = platypus (egg laying)
    + *Maruspials* = pouched mammals
    + *Eutherians* = placental mammals

<br/>

* **Derived Trait: <span style="color:blue">Mammary glands</span>**
    + produce milk for offspring
    
<br/>

* **Derived Trait: <span style="color:blue">Hair</span>**
    + insulation/water saver
<br/>

</div>
